title: 110_s1761
content: The "Safety and Accountability in Construction Act" may be cited as the official title. Highway safety is addressed in the Act. The "Safety and Accountability in Construction Act" addresses highway safety by amending Section 106(a)(1) of title 23, United States Code to require submission of project management plans and adding a new section for independent safety reviews conducted by qualified engineers to analyze highway projects financed with Federal funds for public safety concerns. The "Safety and Accountability in Construction Act" requires an independent engineer to conduct safety reviews for highway projects with Federal funding if there are significant cost overruns or safety concerns. The engineer must be a registered professional with experience in highway projects and no prior association with the project. The "Safety and Accountability in Construction Act" mandates an independent engineer for safety reviews of highway projects with Federal funding. The engineer must be experienced in highway projects and have no prior association with the project. If selected, notification is required to relevant Congressional committees. The "Safety and Accountability in Construction Act" requires contractors involved in highway projects to provide an independent engineer with access to project plans, records, and construction sites. Contracts must authorize the Secretary of Transportation to conduct safety reviews and ensure compliance. The independent engineer must provide analysis findings at the end of the review. The independent engineer must submit analysis findings to the Secretary of Transportation, Inspector General of the Department of Transportation, Administrator of the Federal Highway Administration, and the transportation department of the State. The Inspector General ensures compliance and reports to the Secretary of Transportation, Administrator of the Federal Highway Administration, and appropriate congressional committees. The independent engineer must submit analysis findings to the Secretary of Transportation, Inspector General, Administrator of the Federal Highway Administration, and State transportation department. Authorization of $15,000,000 for each fiscal year is authorized for this section. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in title 23, United States Code. SEC. 3. TUNNEL INSPECTIONS. In General, Section 151 of title 23, United States Code, is amended to include tunnels in addition to bridges for inspection programs. The Surface Transportation Program under Section 133(b)(1) of title 23 is also updated to include tunnels. Section 151 of title 23, United States Code, is amended to include tunnels for inspection programs.
